comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -524,6 +524,12 @@ static const ssl_trace_tbl ssl_groups_tbl[] = {
     {28, "brainpoolP512r1"},
     {29, "ecdh_x25519"},
     {30, "ecdh_x448"},
+    /* OQS groups. 
+       FIXMEOQS: should we use code points between 0x01FC..0x01F,
+       reserved for private-use finite field groups? */
comment.body: I've sent an email to Eric Rescorla asking him what code points we should use in this case.

pull_request.title: OQS integration into OpenSSL's master TLS 1.3 code
pull_request.body:
This PR integrates PQC and hybrid KEX into the OpenSSL 1.1.1 TLS 1.3 code (master branch, beta4). Only non-deprecated KEX from OQS's master branch are integrated.

See README.md for details.

Once reviewed, merge to a separate branch to keep changes clear.

(supersedes pr24, re-submitted for cleaner diff due to out of sync branch)

repo.name: openssl
repo.description: Fork of OpenSSL that includes quantum-resistant algorithms and ciphersuites based on liboqs.

repo.name: openssl
repo.description: Fork of OpenSSL that includes quantum-resistant algorithms and ciphersuites based on liboqs.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,64 @@
+/* Extras for OQS extension */
+
+#define ENCODE_UINT32(pbuf, i)  (pbuf)[index]   = (unsigned char)((i>>24) & 0xff); \
+                                (pbuf)[index+1] = (unsigned char)((i>>16) & 0xff); \
+				(pbuf)[index+2] = (unsigned char)((i>> 8) & 0xff); \
+				(pbuf)[index+3] = (unsigned char)((i    ) & 0xff)
+#define DECODE_UINT32(i, pbuf)  i  = ((uint32_t) (pbuf)[index])   << 24; \
+                                i |= ((uint32_t) (pbuf)[index+1]) << 16; \
+				i |= ((uint32_t) (pbuf)[index+2]) <<  8; \
+				i |= ((uint32_t) (pbuf)[index+3])
+
+/* Encodes two messages (classical and PQC) into one hybrid message:
+   msg1_len || msg1 || msg2_len || msg2
+   hybrid_msg is allocated in this function.
+ */
+static int OQS_encode_hybrid_message(const unsigned char* msg1, uint32_t  msg1_len,

repo.name: openssl
repo.description: Fork of OpenSSL that includes quantum-resistant algorithms and ciphersuites based on liboqs.

repo.name: openssl
repo.description: Fork of OpenSSL that includes quantum-resistant algorithms and ciphersuites based on liboqs.

comment.body: I know that using vendor/liboqs is following what we did in our first fork of OpenSSL 1.0.2.  But in the newer OpenSSL 1.0.2 fork that links against liboqs nist-branch, I kept liboqs outside the project, and then users would first to a `make install` of liboqs to an appropriate location, and then point OpenSSL's build process to that location.  Do you think that would be possible/preferable here?
